text: [Enter Sampson and Gregory armed with swords and bucklers.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: No, for then we should be colliers.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I mean, an we be in choler we'll draw.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the collar.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I strike quickly, being moved.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: therefore, if thou art moved, thou runn'st away.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: A dog of that house shall move me to stand:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I will take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes to the
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: wall.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push Montague's men
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: from the wall and thrust his maids to the wall.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: 'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: when I have fought with the men I will be cruel with the maids,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I will cut off their heads.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: The heads of the maids?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: take it in what sense thou wilt.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: They must take it in sense that feel it.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: and 'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: 'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: thou hadst been poor-John.--Draw thy tool;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Here comes two of the house of Montagues.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: My naked weapon is out: quarrel! I will back thee.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: How! turn thy back and run?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Fear me not.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: No, marry; I fear thee!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I will frown as I pass by; and let them take it as they
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: list.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them; which is
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: disgrace to them if they bear it.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [Enter Abraham and Balthasar.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Abraham.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I do bite my thumb, sir.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Abraham.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Is the law of our side if I say ay?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: No.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir; but I bite my
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: thumb, sir.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Gregory.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Do you quarrel, sir?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Abraham.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Quarrel, sir! no, sir.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: But if you do, sir, am for you: I serve as good a man as
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: you.

text: Abraham.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: No better.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Well, sir.

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Yes, better, sir.

text: Abraham.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: You lie.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Sampson.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Draw, if you be men.--Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [They fight.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [Enter Benvolio.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Part, fools! put up your swords; you know not what you do.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [Beats down their swords.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [Enter Tybalt.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Tybalt.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Turn thee Benvolio, look upon thy death.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Or manage it to part these men with me.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Tybalt.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: What, drawn, and talk of peace! I hate the word
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Have at thee, coward!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [They fight.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [Enter several of both Houses, who join the fray; then enter
title: Romeo and Juliet

title: Romeo and Juliet

text: 1 Citizen.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Clubs, bills, and partisans! strike! beat them down!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Down with the Capulets! Down with the Montagues!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [Enter Capulet in his gown, and Lady Capulet.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Capulet.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: What noise is this?--Give me my long sword, ho!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Lady Capulet.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: A crutch, a crutch!--Why call you for a sword?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Capulet.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: My sword, I say!--Old Montague is come,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And flourishes his blade in spite of me.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [Enter Montague and his Lady  Montague.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Montague.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Thou villain Capulet!-- Hold me not, let me go.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Lady  Montague.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Thou shalt not stir one foot to seek a foe.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [Enter Prince, with Attendants.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Prince.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Will they not hear?--What, ho! you men, you beasts,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: That quench the fire of your pernicious rage
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: With purple fountains issuing from your veins,--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: On pain of torture, from those bloody hands
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And hear the sentence of your moved prince.--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our streets;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And made Verona's ancient citizens
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: To wield old partisans, in hands as old,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Canker'd with peace, to part your canker'd hate:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: If ever you disturb our streets again,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: For this time, all the rest depart away:--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: You, Capulet, shall go along with me;--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And, Montague, come you this afternoon,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: To know our farther pleasure in this case,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: [Exeunt Prince and Attendants; Capulet, Lady Capulet, Tybalt,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Citizens, and Servants.]
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Montague.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Here were the servants of your adversary
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And yours, close fighting ere I did approach:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I drew to part them: in the instant came
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepar'd;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Which, as he breath'd defiance to my ears,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: He swung about his head, and cut the winds,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Who, nothing hurt withal, hiss'd him in scorn:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Came more and more, and fought on part and part,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Till the prince came, who parted either part.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Lady Montague.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: O, where is Romeo?--saw you him to-day?--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Right glad I am he was not at this fray.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Peer'd forth the golden window of the east,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Where,--underneath the grove of sycamore
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: That westward rooteth from the city's side,--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: So early walking did I see your son:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Towards him I made; but he was ware of me,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And stole into the covert of the wood:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I, measuring his affections by my own,--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: That most are busied when they're most alone,--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Pursu'd my humour, not pursuing his,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Montague.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Many a morning hath he there been seen,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: With tears augmenting the fresh morning's dew,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: But all so soon as the all-cheering sun
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Should in the farthest east begin to draw
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: The shady curtains from Aurora's bed,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Away from light steals home my heavy son,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And private in his chamber pens himself;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And makes himself an artificial night:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Black and portentous must this humour prove,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Unless good counsel may the cause remove.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Montague.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I neither know it nor can learn of him.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Have you importun'd him by any means?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Montague.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Both by myself and many other friends;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: But he, his own affections' counsellor,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Is to himself,--I will not say how true,--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: But to himself so secret and so close,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: So far from sounding and discovery,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: As is the bud bit with an envious worm
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: We would as willingly give cure as know.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: See, where he comes: so please you step aside;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I'll know his grievance or be much denied.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Montague.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: To hear true shrift.--Come, madam, let's away,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Good morrow, cousin.

text: Romeo.

text: But new struck nine.

text: Romeo.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.

text: Romeo.

text: Not having that which, having, makes them short.

text: Out,--

title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Romeo.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Out of her favour where I am in love.

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Alas, that love, so gentle in his view,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Romeo.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Alas that love, whose view is muffled still,

text: Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will!--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Where shall we dine?--O me!--What fray was here?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Here's much to do with hate, but more with love:--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: O anything, of nothing first create!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: O heavy lightness! serious vanity!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health!
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: This love feel I, that feel no love in this.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Dost thou not laugh?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: No, coz, I rather weep.

text: Romeo.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Good heart, at what?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: At thy good heart's oppression.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Romeo.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Why, such is love's transgression.--
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: With more of thine: this love that thou hast shown
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Love is a smoke rais'd with the fume of sighs;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Being purg'd, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes;
title: Romeo and Juliet

title: Romeo and Juliet

text: A choking gall, and a preserving sweet.--

text: Farewell, my coz.

text: [Going.]

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Soft! I will go along:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.

text: Romeo.

text: Tut! I have lost myself; I am not here:

text: This is not Romeo, he's some other where.

text: Romeo.

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Groan!  why, no;

text: Ah, word ill urg'd to one that is so ill!--

text: In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: I aim'd so near when I suppos'd you lov'd.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Romeo.

text: A right good markman!--And she's fair I love.

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Romeo.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: With Cupid's arrow,--she hath Dian's wit;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: She will not stay the siege of loving terms
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Nor bide th' encounter of assailing eyes,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: O, she's rich in beauty; only poor
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: That, when she dies, with beauty dies her store.

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Romeo.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste;
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: For beauty, starv'd with her severity,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: She is too fair, too wise; wisely too fair,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: To merit bliss by making me despair:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: She hath forsworn to love; and in that vow
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Do I live dead that live to tell it now.

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Be rul'd by me, forget to think of her.

text: Benvolio.
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: By giving liberty unto thine eyes;

text: Examine other beauties.

text: Romeo.

text: 'Tis the way
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: To call hers, exquisite, in question more:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows,
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair;

title: Romeo and Juliet

text: The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:
title: Romeo and Juliet

text: Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair?

text: Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.

text: Benvolio.

text: I sheathe again undeeded. There thou shouldst be;

text: By this great clatter, one of greatest note

text: Seems bruited. Let me find him, fortune!

text: MACBETH.

text: Thou losest labour:

text: As easy mayst thou the intrenchant air

text: With thy keen sword impress, as make me bleed:

text: Let fall thy blade on vulnerable crests;

text: Despair thy charm;

text: For it hath cow'd my better part of man!

text: And be these juggling fiends no more believ'd,

text: That palter with us in a double sense;

text: That keep the word of promise to our ear,

text: And break it to our hope!--I'll not fight with thee.

text: Then yield thee, coward,

text: And live to be the show and gaze o' the time:
